content.body:
> <@lucacasonato:matrix.org> It looks like api.csswg.org may be having some issues. My CI runs are failing on the fetch spec: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/runs/5472598698?check_suite_focus=true

https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 — which hasn’t been re-closed yet, so I don’t know if that means they’re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @lucacasonato:matrix.org
It looks like api.csswg.org may be having some issues. My CI runs are failing on the fetch spec: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/runs/5472598698?check_suite_focus=true
https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 — which hasn’t been re-closed yet, so I don’t know if that means they’re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.

https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 — which hasn’t been re-closed yet, so I don’t know if that means they’re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.

In reply to @lucacasonato:matrix.org
It looks like api.csswg.org may be having some issues. My CI runs are failing on the fetch spec: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/runs/5472598698?check_suite_focus=true
https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 — which hasn’t been re-closed yet, so I don’t know if that means they’re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.

content.body: Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term _“same-site”_?
content.formatted_body: Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term “same-site”?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term _“same-site”_?
Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term “same-site”?

content.body: I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for  the `same-site` value of the `Sec-Fetch-Site` header — and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 — but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by “same-site” (at least it’s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)
content.formatted_body: I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for the same-site value of the Sec-Fetch-Site header — and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 — but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by “same-site” (at least it’s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for  the `same-site` value of the `Sec-Fetch-Site` header — and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 — but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by “same-site” (at least it’s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)

I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for the same-site value of the Sec-Fetch-Site header — and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 — but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by “same-site” (at least it’s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)

content.body: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#same-site
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#same-site

content.body: Andreu Botella: OK thanks yeah I had seen that. So I guess that’s the best we’ve got — but I doubt it’s going to mean much to the average web developer reading it.
content.formatted_body: Andreu Botella: OK thanks yeah I had seen that. So I guess that’s the best we’ve got — but I doubt it’s going to mean much to the average web developer reading it.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Andreu Botella: OK thanks yeah I had seen that. So I guess that’s the best we’ve got — but I doubt it’s going to mean much to the average web developer reading it.
Andreu Botella: OK thanks yeah I had seen that. So I guess that’s the best we’ve got — but I doubt it’s going to mean much to the average web developer reading it.

content.body: That seems to be the normative definition. I agree that it's not great for average devs
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That seems to be the normative definition. I agree that it's not great for average devs

content.body: …it doesn’t even directly reference _“registrable domain”_
content.formatted_body: …it doesn’t even directly reference “registrable domain”

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: …it doesn’t even directly reference _“registrable domain”_
…it doesn’t even directly reference “registrable domain”

content.body: yeah
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: yeah

content.body: I think the concept of “registrable domain” is very clear and intuitive to everybody, so I’m glad that was coined and we have that defined in (the URL spec) at least — it’s been a big improvement over directly mentioning the public-suffix list and the “eTLD+1” term
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think the concept of “registrable domain” is very clear and intuitive to everybody, so I’m glad that was coined and we have that defined in (the URL spec) at least — it’s been a big improvement over directly mentioning the public-suffix list and the “eTLD+1” term

content.body:
by the way, I’m confused a bit by https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#sites, where we have the term “site” defined as this:
> A site is an opaque origin or a scheme-and-host

…while “obtain a site”, in the common case, reduces defined as this:
> origin's scheme, origin's host's registrable domain

content.body: Yes, I knew about the issue; CI reported it to me right at the end of the day. Unfortunately the API server runs tip-of-tree Bikeshed (and is running 3.7, the version that was having problems), so it was broken until just now when I fixed it.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yes, I knew about the issue; CI reported it to me right at the end of the day. Unfortunately the API server runs tip-of-tree Bikeshed (and is running 3.7, the version that was having problems), so it was broken until just now when I fixed it.

content.body: (Anything running pip-installed Bikeshed should, to the best of my ability, always work great; at minimum, I verify it cycles green before I push new versions, and try to push versions soon after new fixes or features.)
